steps.title: The Superpower
steps.narration: Here's a superpower most people don't have: the ability to see data everywhere. Right now, you're surrounded by information. Every post, every review, every comment ‚Äî it's all data waiting to be discovered.

steps.title: Social Media as Phone Book
steps.narration: Think of social media as a phone book of data. It's not just people posting selfies ‚Äî it's millions of people telling you what they think, what they want, what problems they have. All for free.

steps.title: Data Sources Everywhere
steps.narration: Social media shows opinions and trends. Reviews reveal what people love and hate. Comments show real reactions. Local listings, news, public stats ‚Äî data is literally everywhere once you learn to see it.

steps.title: Data Becomes Insight
steps.narration: And here's the key: data, when you know how to collect and analyze it, becomes insight. Insight is understanding. Understanding leads to solutions. This is how problem solvers operate.

stories.title: Two Algorithms That Rule Your Life

steps.title: Two Algorithms
steps.narration: There are two algorithms you need to understand because they control most of how you find and receive information. One puts you in control. The other puts the platform in control.

steps.title: Search Algorithm
steps.narration: Search: you have a goal, you go find it. When you search Google or YouTube, you decide what you want and the algorithm tries to match it. Better search terms equal better results. This is a skill.

steps.title: Recommendation Algorithm
steps.narration: Recommendation: the platform decides what you see. Your TikTok feed, YouTube homepage, Instagram Explore ‚Äî they watch what you engage with and show you more of the same. Designed to keep you watching.

steps.title: The Critical Difference
steps.narration: Search: you're in control, you choose what to find. Recommendation: the algorithm chooses what you see. Problem solvers use search more than recommendation. They know what they're looking for and go get it.

steps.title: Be Intentional
steps.narration: Don't let algorithms choose your information for you. Be intentional about what you engage with. When you need to learn something, search for it. Don't wait for it to be recommended.

steps.title: Collection is Simple
steps.narration: Data collection isn't complicated. It's just being intentional about gathering information instead of passively scrolling past it. You see data every day ‚Äî you just need to capture it.

steps.title: The Collection Pattern
steps.narration: The pattern: define what you want to know, identify where the data lives, collect it systematically, then look for patterns. Simple process, powerful results.

steps.title: Look for Patterns
steps.narration: Raw data is just numbers and words. Insights come from patterns. If ten reviews mention slow service, that's a pattern. If everyone praises the vibe, that's a pattern. Patterns reveal truth.

steps.title: Ask Why
steps.narration: Once you see patterns, ask why. Why do people complain about this? Why do they love that? Go deeper than the surface. Use your six levels deep skills to understand root causes.

steps.title: Find the Gaps
steps.narration: What's missing? What are people asking for that doesn't exist? Gaps equal opportunities. Every unmet need is a potential solution waiting to be built. Data reveals where to focus.

steps.title: Draw Conclusions
steps.narration: Based on the patterns, what can you conclude? What would you recommend? This is where data becomes useful ‚Äî when it informs action. Analysis without action is just trivia.

questions.question: What's the 'superpower' described in the Data Mindset?
options: The ability to see data everywhere
Having lots of social media followers
questions.explanation: The superpower is seeing data everywhere ‚Äî recognizing that every review, comment, post, and interaction contains information that can be collected and analyzed for insights.

questions.question: What does 'social media as a phone book' mean?
options: You can find phone numbers on social media
It's millions of people sharing their thoughts, problems, and wants ‚Äî free data
Social media is outdated like phone books
You should call people instead of messaging
questions.explanation: Social media is like a phone book of data ‚Äî millions of people freely sharing what they think, want, and struggle with. It's a massive source of insights if you know how to look.

questions.question: What's the relationship between data and insight?
options: Data is raw information; insight is understanding that comes from analyzing it
Data is more valuable than insight
questions.explanation: Data is raw information (numbers, comments, reviews). Insight is the understanding you gain when you analyze data for patterns. Data ‚Üí Analysis ‚Üí Insight ‚Üí Solutions.

questions.question: What's the key difference between search and recommendation algorithms?
options: Search: you're in control; Recommendation: the algorithm chooses for you
questions.explanation: With search, YOU decide what to find. With recommendations, the ALGORITHM decides what you see. Problem solvers prefer search because they stay in control of their information diet.

questions.question: Why do problem solvers use search more than recommendations?
options: Search is free, recommendations cost money
They know what they're looking for and go get it intentionally
questions.explanation: Problem solvers are intentional. They know what information they need and actively search for it rather than passively consuming whatever an algorithm serves them.

questions.question: What's the danger of relying too heavily on recommendation algorithms?
options: They're designed to keep you watching, not necessarily to help you
questions.explanation: Recommendation algorithms are optimized for engagement (keeping you watching) not for your benefit. They can trap you in filter bubbles and distract you from intentional learning.

questions.question: What's the data collection pattern?
options: Define what you want ‚Üí Find where data lives ‚Üí Collect systematically ‚Üí Look for patterns
Only collect data from official sources
questions.explanation: The pattern is: (1) Define what you want to know, (2) Identify where that data exists, (3) Collect it systematically, (4) Analyze for patterns. Simple and effective.

questions.question: What turns raw data into insights?
questions.explanation: Insights come from finding patterns in data and asking why those patterns exist. Ten reviews mentioning 'slow service' is a pattern; understanding WHY service is slow is insight.

questions.question: Why are 'gaps' important when analyzing data?
options: Gaps indicate errors in your data
Gaps (unmet needs) represent opportunities for solutions
Gaps mean you need more data
questions.explanation: Gaps are opportunities! When people ask for something that doesn't exist, that's an unmet need. Every gap is a potential solution waiting to be built.
